children.subject: What is the difference between a major in L&S and a major in L&S administered by CoE department? What causes there to be a difference? Sorry if this is a stupid question but I don't remember seeing an explanation anywhere.

<md>The differences are various and subtle. Almost all majors and minors within L&S are administered by departments in L&S. CS is an exception. There are others. Each special case has its own arrangement. These kinds of administrative distinctions usually don't affect/confuse students so directly, but this time they do. </md>
<md>Minor requirements for minors administered by the EECS department (EECS, CS, and EIS) will also follow the CoE policy, which currently requires a letter grade for degree requirements.</md>

my bad, didn't read the whole post 🤡

my question stands though-- what if I am trying to use a non-EECS/CS class to fulfill a tech elective for the CS major?

<md>Technical electives are major requirements, not college requirements, and so should be taken for a letter grade.

As for an explanation: In some administrative sense, the L&S CS major is not a College major for the College of L&S, despite its name, since it is administered by CoE. This fact is confusing to students, faculty, and staff alike. The good news is that the CS major exists at all despite its unusual cross-college nature. The bad news is that its governance can be complicated. In this case, the EECS faculty and staff did discuss the issue with both the College of L&S and College of Engineering and consider the implications, and what you see in this post is the result of those conversations.</md>

thanks for the update! could you explain how this doesn't contradict point #2 on the overall L&S policy, which states that "Requirements within all College majors and minors may be met by courses that are taken P/NP during the Fall 2020, Spring 2021, and Summer 2021 terms"? I am asking specifically about a technical elective that I'm taking over the summer, but this is a general question too.
<md>Yes, 61C must be taken for a letter grade to fulfill major/minor requirements.</md>
Just to clarify, we cannot take CS61C in summer 2021 as P/NP, right?
No, if you're using it for your major requirements
Would lower-div courses like CS 61C require a letter grade for degree/minor requirements?
<md>I can't predict the future, but I think a change is unlikely at this point.</md>
Is this policy still subject to change? How likely would CoE change its decision?
As long as you cancel before the deadline for your first enrolled session
You'll get full refund with no cancellation fee if you drop a class before it starts.

I was enrolled in 61C for this summer with plans to take it P/NP since I'm also doing an internship over summer, so this comes as a shock to me. Is there any chance I can get a refund on summer fees if I drop the class?
Damn. This comes as a surprise. I'd built my summer commitments with respect to this.
<md>Correct (if you want the course to count toward your major requirements).</md>
<md>I met with L&S advisors and CS advisors and they said the PNP classes I took over Spring 2021 count towards CS major requirements. This still stands, right?</md>
<md>Yes. </md>
<md>If I'm an L&S CS major taking a CS upper div class over the summer, I have to take the class for a grade? </md>

is there a history of the CS major following CoE as opposed to L&S policy in regards to stuff like this? because I think for the general PNP policy for the past fall and spring semesters, we CS majors followed the L&S, not CoE rules (please correct me if I'm mistaken). I sympathize with Calc-- I'm doing an internship + a summer class + other commitments because I assumed that we would be following the L&S policy, which as mentioned, had been released with a good amount of advance notice for us to plan our summer and fall semesters. This assumption was my mistake, of course, but I am not sure if there was some implicit expectation for me to not make such an assumption after an official announcement from the college that I have been in for my whole time at this school. this will not have been my first time making an administrative booboo so I could have misread something, and I'm really just trying to understand.

even if CoE always has the right to make these decisions, was there no way that this could have been announced further in advance? session C, which is when my course and a lot of the other CS major requirement courses start, is less than three weeks out. I'm sure there are administrative difficulties in making such a decision and I really am grateful for the continued support-- but we have had more than two fully online semesters at this point, so (in addition to Calc's point about the same student struggles existing over the summer) the CS department should already have a decent idea of how things play out in terms of pedagogy (I was told by an advisor that this decision might be motivated by concerns like cheating, inequality in group work, diminishing quality of curriculum and learning, etc**) so I am curious about what new information was needed to make this decision so late. thank you!

**I am paraphrasing what I was told on a call when checking my degree progress more than a month ago. I could have forgotten, so this is in no way an official representation of the decision made and why-- just what I recall being told.

<md>Thank you both for your input on this decision.

First of all, I agree that the timing of this announcement is unfortunate. I'm sorry that clarity on this issue wasn't provided sooner. These decisions are not made lightly because we are aware of how they affect students' plans and experience.

That said, I would encourage all students taking summer courses to allocate adequate time in order to master the course material. Summer courses can be a great experience even at their accelerated pace, but do require a substantial amount of dedicated time each week.

Regarding whether the CS major was subject to the L&S policy in Fall and Spring, the answer is no, but there was quite a bit of confusion about that question among administrators at the time. Some people thought it was at first, so I'm sure you can find announcements saying that it was, but in fact it was not. In the end, the distinction didn't matter because both L&S and CoE eventually adopted equivalent P/NP policies for the Fall and Spring. 
</md>

<md>After revisiting this issue with the College of Letters and Sciences leadership based on your feedback, we have amended the announcement slightly, but not in a way that affects CS 162. Thanks again for your input. I'm sorry that your request was not fulfilled, but it was discussed.</md>
So, does it now mean that 61A can be taken as P/Np and still count towards declaration and degree? Sorry, I got confused while reading the post.

<md>Yes, 61A can be taken P/NP and still count toward declaration, but (and this part is really important) you will be assigned a letter grade anyway, and that letter grade will be used for declaration. Taking 61A P/NP will not increase your chances of declaring or let you omit your 61A grade from your declaration GPA. All that is achieved by taking 61A P/NP is to omit your letter grade from your university transcript.</md>

What an awful surprise. How can you pull the rug out just two weeks before the start of the summer session? Many of us built our schedules for Summer and Fall around the expectation of a Summer PNP option. I know I'm not the best CS student at Berkeley, so it was a relief to me to know that when I enrolled in CS 162 for this summer I would have the PNP option as a lifeboat if things go sideways. So now I'm set to take a difficult course at double speed without the promised PNP option. Learning about this change so late I can't now simply defer CS 162 to the Fall since the course is totally booked at this point. Deferring to the spring is not an option for me either since I'm set to graduate in the Fall.

As of June 6 the L&S advising page ( https://lsadvising.berkeley.edu/policies/covid-policy-modifications/summer-2021-policy-modifications-and-faq ) says about Summer 2021:  "Requirements within all College majors and minors may be met by courses that are taken P/NP during the Fall 2020, Spring 2021, and Summer 2021 terms. "

I understand that the College of Engineering has decided not to extend its P/NP policy to the summer. I understand that CoE plays a role in administering the CS major. But, special or not, the CS major is part of the College of Letters and Science and should be amenable to the Summer 2021 policy, announced in April, that L&S describes on its webpage.

Moreover, the summer courses are still going to be delivered remotely. In this regard, there will not be a meaningful difference in the student experience come summer. Whatever level of cheating or corruption of the curve that was present in Fall and Spring is apt to appear during the remote summer. Whatever difficulties and inconveniences of remote study--be it the difficulty of finding a suitable study space or working remotely in groups (as one must in CS)--will be no less real than they were in the Spring. It must have been for these reasons and more that L&S decided to extend its PNP policy and so as CS students we should be allowed to take advantage of the policy that our college offers rather than be exceptionally excluded from using it.

I wish the College of Engineering would reconsider this decision and I encourage any students who feels similarly to share their opinions with the L&S advising staff: see https://lsadvising.berkeley.edu/appointments-advice/ls-advising-staff-0  (click on senior staff)
and if we took PNP for those courses in Fall 2020 and Spring 2021, will we still be eligible for the CS Minor?

<md>There's no L&S CS minor. Instead, the CS minor is administered by the College of Engineering. Courses taken P/NP in Spring 2020, Fall 2020, and Spring 2021 count toward the CS minor, but courses taken Summer 2021 should be taken for a letter grade.

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/minor</md>

This makes it extremely difficult if we needed to PNP our summer class and ended up not being able to declare for the major. Then, we don't even have the option to be eligible for the minor which is extremely discouraging. It feels very ridiculous that the L&S CS major and the minor follow different policies and provides added distress when trying to make a decision during these trying times.

<md>It is always possible to petition if you P/NP a course for which you later need a letter grade, but my advice is that you should just take these courses for a letter grade.

I share your opinion that different P/NP policies for different degrees is ridiculous. I think the campus should have adopted a uniform policy. I'm sorry that it hasn't worked out that way.</md>
How does the recent update impact the L&S CS minor? Will we still be able to PNP CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70 to be eligible for the CS minor?
<md>If you want credit toward the L&S CS major, then PNP is only allowed for 61A, 61B, and 70.</md>
clarification on the edit, is PNP only allowed for 61a,61b, and 70 and no other CS classes?

https://summer.berkeley.edu/registration/schedule

Should be August 6, for session C.
Is there no deadline to switch to PNP for summer?
If you pass a class you can’t retake it, except in the cases of like special topics class where the content changes from semester to semester even if the class number stays the same
If I take 61C P/NP this summer can I take it for a grade in the fall?
<md>Please ask your instructor.</md>
How can I see the grade I would have gotten in a summer class if I'm taking it PNP?

history.content:
Whether or not courses taken P/NP in Summer 2021 fulfill major requirements for L&S Computer Science will be determined by the College of Engineering policy. The College of Engineering has (so far) decided not to extended its P/NP policy from Fall 2020 and Spring 2021. Therefore, students majoring or intending to major in L&S Computer Science taking Summer 2021 courses that fulfill major requirements should elect the letter grading option.

Some college-level degree requirements for the L&S Computer Science major, such as the R&C requirement, may be fulfilled by courses taken P/NP. The L&S Summer 2021 policy applies to these courses.

Both the EECS and L&S CS majors are administered by the EECS department. While the L&S Summer 2021 policy states that, “Requirements within all College majors and minors may be met by courses that are taken P/NP,” the L&S CS major is a special case because it is administered by the EECS department within the CoE. For this reason, the policy for major requirements will follow the CoE college-level policy, which requires that major courses be taken for a letter grade.

Update (June 23): This announcement is being amended slightly. At the request of the College of Letters and Sciences, the declaration policy for L&S CS from Fall 2020 and Spring 2021 will extend into Summer 2021. This change only affects CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70. Electing P/NP grading for CS 61A, CS 61B, or CS 70 in Summer 2021 will neither help nor hinder a student’s application to declare the L&S Computer Science major. Letter grades will be computed for all students in these three courses, regardless of the grading option they elect (letter grade or P/NP). For L&S CS major admission purposes, only the letter grades computed in this way will be used to determine the declaration GPA. Because these three courses may be taken P/NP for declaration, they may also be taken P/NP to fulfill the L&S CS major degree requirements. The implication of this update is that all L&S students may take 61A, 61B, or 70 P/NP during Summer 2021, including CS-intended students. The College of L&S and the EECS department both encourage all students to take courses for a letter grade if able. Moreover, letter grades will be computed and will affect CS declaration eligibility even for students who take these courses P/NP. Students majoring or intending to major in L&S Computer Science taking any other Summer 2021 courses that fulfill major requirements should still elect the letter grading option, as stated above.
history.subject: Summer 2021 P/NP Policy for the L&S CS major
